Which statements about the behavior of gaseous H2 molecules in a container at 1 atm and 298 K are correct? I. All H2 molecules are moving at the same speed. II. The H2 molecules are colliding more frequently with the walls of the container than they would in the same container at 398 K.

A sample of methanol, CH3OH, is introduced into an evacuated chamber with a movable piston. The pressure is measured as a function of the volume of the container while the temperature is maintained at 50 ºC, and the graph below is obtained. 400 350 mmHg , P 300 250 200 20 40 60 V, mL 80 100 120 Which statements are correct? text: The standard enthalpy of formation, ∆Hºf, for HCOOH(l) is equal to the standard enthalpy change for which reaction?

40.0 mL of 0.200 M aqueous NaOH is added to 200.0 mL of 0.100 M aqueous NaHCO3 in a flask maintained at 25 ºC. Neglecting the effects of dilution, what is q for this reaction? ∆Hºf, kJ mol–1 OH–(aq) –230 HCO3–(aq) –692 CO32–(aq) –677 H2O(l) –286
g water at 32.0 ºC. What is the final temperature when the mixture reaches equilibrium? (The heat of fusion of ice is 334 J g–1.)
Which is the best explanation for the negative sign of ∆Sº in the following reaction? CaSO4(s)  Ca2+(aq) + SO42–(aq) ∆Sº = –143 J mol–1 K–1

options.A: There are more ways of arranging the Ca2+ and SO42– ions in aqueous solution than in the crystal lattice.
options.B: Solid CaSO4 is a network covalent solid, whereas it separates into ions in aqueous solution.
options.C: Aqueous Ca2+ and SO42– ions are tightly solvated, decreasing the number of ways of arranging water molecules when the solid dissolves.
options.D: Calcium sulfate dissolves exothermically, leading to a net loss of entropy.

text: The Ksp of Al(OH)3 is 2.0  10–31 at 298 K. What is ∆Gº (at 298 K) for the precipitation of Al(OH)3 according to the equation below? Al3+(aq) + 3 OH–(aq)  Al(OH)3(s)
What is the bond dissociation enthalpy of the Cl–Cl bond?
Which statement about chemical reaction mechanisms is correct?

options.A: The overall rate law can be determined from any step in the mechanism.
options.B: The rate of a reaction is the rate of the fastest elementary step of its mechanism.
options.C: The chemical equation for the sum of all the elementary steps is the chemical equation of the overall reaction.
options.D: Species that are produced and subsequently consumed in the mechanism serve as catalysts for the reaction.

Which of the following statements is best supported by the data from Rutherford’s experiment of scattering alpha particles with a thin metal foil?

options.A: The mass and positive charge of an atom are concentrated in its center.
options.B: Electrons in atoms occupy only certain specific energy levels.
options.C: Moving particles can also be described as waves.
options.D: Atoms of a given element do not all have identical masses.

Nitrogen has a greater first ionization energy than oxygen. What is the best explanation for this observation?

options.A: Nitrogen is more electronegative than oxygen.
options.B: A nitrogen atom is smaller than an oxygen atom.
options.C: The electron ionized from nitrogen experiences less electron-electron repulsion than the electron ionized from oxygen.
options.D: The electron ionized from nitrogen is a 2s electron, while the electron ionized from oxygen is a 2p electron.

Which is not a stable molecule?
What is the molecular geometry of IF3?
Which is the best explanation for this difference?

options.A: N2 has valence electrons only in bonding and nonbonding orbitals, while P2 has some valence electrons in antibonding orbitals.
options.B: The greater electronegativity of N compared to P stabilizes compounds with lower molar masses.
options.C: The greater size of P compared to N results in decreased overlap in pi bonds.
options.D: The preference of P to adopt smaller bond angles than N favors formation of tetrahedral P4 molecules.
